reactions.name: Glycolysis (net reaction)
reactions.equation: C6H12O6(s) + 2 NAD+(aq) + 2 ADP(aq) + 2 Pi(aq) -> 2 CH3COCOO-(aq) + 2 NADH(aq) + 2 ATP(aq) + 2 H2O(l)
reactions.description: Glucose to 2 pyruvate. Net 2 ATP + 2 NADH. Universal pathway in all domains of life.

reactions.name: Krebs cycle (overall per acetyl-CoA)
reactions.equation: Acetyl-CoA + 3 NAD+ + FAD + GDP + Pi + 2 H2O -> CoA-SH + 2 CO2 + 3 NADH + FADH2 + GTP
reactions.conditions: mitochondrial matrix; 8 enzyme-catalyzed steps; regulated by [ATP]/[ADP]
reactions.description: Central metabolic hub. Oxidizes acetyl groups to CO2, generating electron carriers for ETC.

reactions.name: Hydroxyapatite formation (bone mineralization)
reactions.conditions: osteoblast-mediated; alkaline phosphatase; collagen matrix template
reactions.description: Hydroxyapatite is the mineral component of bone and teeth. ~70% of bone mass.

reactions.name: ATP hydrolysis
reactions.description: Universal energy currency of life. Drives endergonic reactions by coupling. ~100 kg ATP recycled/day in humans.

reactions.name: ATP synthesis (oxidative phosphorylation)
reactions.conditions: ATP synthase (Complex V); proton motive force across inner mitochondrial membrane
reactions.description: Chemiosmotic synthesis of ATP. F1Fo-ATP synthase rotary motor. ~26-28 ATP from one glucose.

reactions.name: Phosphorus production (electric arc furnace)
reactions.equation: 2 Ca3(PO4)2(s) + 6 SiO2(s) + 10 C(s) -> P4(g) + 6 CaSiO3(l) + 10 CO(g)
reactions.conditions: 1773 K; electric arc furnace; P4 vapor condensed under water
reactions.description: White phosphorus production from phosphate rock via electric arc furnace.

reactions.name: Phosphoric acid production (wet process)
reactions.description: Wet-process phosphoric acid for fertilizer production. Gypsum (CaSO4) byproduct.

reactions.name: White phosphorus spontaneous combustion
reactions.conditions: pyrophoric; ignites spontaneously in air above ~30C; stored under water
reactions.description: White phosphorus is pyrophoric. Ignites spontaneously in air. Must be stored under water. Extremely toxic.
